ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Unilateral SNHL, tinnitus, and aural fullness combined with positive acoustic reflex decay and delayed ABR latencies strongly indicate retrocochlear pathology.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Noise-Induced Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of unprotected noise exposure explains bilateral high-frequency involvement but does not account for the asymmetry or retrocochlear signs.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Evaluate speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
Screen for retrocochlear pathology via reflex thresholds and decay.
Assess cochlear outer hair cell function.
Electrophysiological assessment to confirm retrocochlear pathway integrity.
Imaging to visualize potential space-occupying lesions in the internal auditory canal.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The initial evaluation revealed asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss (worse in the left ear) with positive acoustic reflex decay in the left ear, raising suspicion for retrocochlear pathology. Subsequent medical workup (ABR and MRI) confirmed a left-sided acoustic neuroma.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal (250-1000 Hz) to slight loss (2000-8000 Hz). Left ear: Slight to moderate SNHL (250-4000 Hz) recovering to mild at 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT: Right 15 dB HL, Left 35 dB HL. WRS: 100% bilaterally at 40 dB SL.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Type Ad (hypercompliant) bilaterally with normal pressure and volume.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds bilaterally. Reflex decay negative in Right ear, positive in Left ear at 500 and 1000 Hz.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Normal latencies in Right ear; delayed peak and interpeak latencies in Left ear.

tests.name: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
tests.result_summary: 4x3x2 mm lesion in the left internal auditory canal (acoustic neuroma).

counseling_actions: Explain asymmetric hearing loss and retrocochlear signs (reflex decay).
Discuss need for medical evaluation (MRI) before considering amplification.
Counsel on ear protection in the presence of loud noise.

escalation.rationale_short: Suspected retrocochlear pathology (acoustic neuroma) requiring medical diagnosis and management.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing thresholds, manage vestibular symptoms, and support vocational rehabilitation.

expected_outcome: Surgery was performed and the left acoustic neuroma was removed.
Patient reported postoperative dizziness and left-sided facial weakness.
Postoperative Pure-tone Audiometry: Significant decrease in hearing sensitivity in the left ear (250-8000 Hz).
Postoperative Speech Audiometry: Left ear SRT 47 dB HL, WRS 92% at 75 dB HL.
Patient unable to continue construction work due to dizziness; pursuing new career via Vocational Rehabilitation.
